bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Pedro Nogueira, March 1, 1954

div1.p: Hench thanks Nogueira for thinking of Cooke's widow, inquires about the decision regarding microfilming Finlay's day books, and discusses bringing the recipients of the Finlay Medals to Washington, D.C. to receive their medals from Nogueira personally.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Pedro Nogueira, March 1, 1954
div1.opener:
March 1, 1954
Dr. Pedro Nogueira
Marti 219, Marianao
Cuba
My dear Pedro:
div1.p:
I have your letter of February 24. I forgot all about Doctor Cooke. Certainly
his widow should have his medal and in order to hurry things along, I am
sending you my own check for $27 to make up the difference. If, however,
the Walter Reed Memorial Association decides to cover that also and send
you a check, you can either return my check or simply destroy it.

Thank you very much for your telegram. I am sorry that Doctor Inclan
and you have not been able to meet with the Board of the Academy of Sciences.
I do hope that soon they will give us permission to have the microfilms
made. Lidia Cabrera assures me that there is a microfilm machine in Havana,
not at the public library but at some technical library. Of course if it
could be loaned through diplomatic channels to the Surgeon General's Library,
you and I could get the copies for much less.

Last week in Washington, I called on General and Mrs. Reed and Blossom Reed,
Hoping that you will come to the U.S. between June 10 and 20, they would
prefer to wait until then rather than have the Cuban embassy present the
medals to them in your absence. The Reeds all hope to be reasonably well
and on hand at that time. However General Reed has for years had a severe
asthma and wheezes considerably on any exertion. Therefore he goes prac-
tically nowhere. However his family assured me that they would see to it
that he went to the Embassy for such a pleasant ceremony.

I also visited Mrs. George Carroll, Major Carroll's daughter-in-law and told
her of the impending honor. She is a rather shy, withdrawn person, rather
afraid of the world and of course, at the moment, disconsolate because of
her husband's death. She lives in modest circumstances and in the past
there has been some feeling between the Carrolls and the Reeds, but I am
sure it is entirely one-sided. Mrs. George Carroll told me that Doctor
Carroll's widow taught the children that he was robbed of his proper
fame by Doctor Reed. This of course was nonsense as Reed was long since
dead and I am sure the Reed family had nothing to do with it; however I am
also sure that they could all meet amicably for the ceremony. I should
think that Mrs. Cooke would come up from Lexington, Virginia, to Washington
for the ceremony at the Embassy and you would, of course, I assume suggest
to the Cuban Ambassador that the recipients be allowed to have a few rela-
tives personal friends as guests, including the members of the Walter Reed
Memorial Association, for the little ceremony. Will you be able to go to
California to help the Consul present the medals to the Lazears and General
Truby?
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:ALC
P.S.: I shall await with eagerness further news regarding the microfilm.
